Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Small: Model-Driven Visual Analytics on Streams

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Risk analysis and monitoring of continuously arriving data are required by a wide range of domains critical to our individual and societal well-being, from the military to the financial sector, from medicine to homeland security, from man-made to natural disasters. These application areas use patterns or models to differentiate behavior of varying degrees of importance or risk, both in terms of the value for a particular variable, relationships between different variables, and changes across time. The objective of this project is the design, development, and assessment of visual analytics technology to support the real-time interactive analysis of data streams that focuses on creating and using models of stream behavior to identify instances of potentially important activities and risks in the data.

The research breaks new ground in the design of innovative exploration techniques of high-volume streaming data, with a focus on visualization and interactions of competing and complementary models extracted from the stream data and of change descriptions derived from each. Novel technology includes computational and visual methods for model formation, management, and model change analysis. Efficient indexing and compression of the history of how data and models change provide analysts with the ability to compare and contrast similar events over long periods of time. Linked views of the different information spaces (data, model, change, and history), and powerful interaction tools to support exploration and model building enable analysts to confirm the expected and uncover the unexpected.

The results of this project are expected to have significant impact is a wide range of domains that rely on extracting information from real-time digital data, including finance, medicine, and homeland security. In particular, tools are developed for solving financial risk and fraud detection problems critical to the economic well-being of individuals and organizations. Educational material from using the technology in courses are freely available, along with source code and data sets, via the project web page (http://davis.wpi.edu/~xmdv).

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Risk analysis and monitoring of evolving data are required by a wide range of domains critical to our individual and societal well-being, from the financial sector to homeland security.  These application areas use patterns or models to differentiate behavior of varying degrees of importance or risk, both in terms of the value for a particular variable, relationships between different variables, and changes across time. This project has designed, developed, and assessed visual analytics technology to support the interactive analysis of data that focuses on creating and using complementary machine learning characterizing the data to identify instances of potentially important activities and risks in the data. 

 

This research breaks fundamentally new ground in the design of innovative exploration techniques of time-variant data sets, with a focus on visualization and interactions of competing and complementary models extracted from the data and of metrics characterizing each. Novel technology includes the integration of computational and visual methods for interactive model formation, model management and model analysis. Linked views of the different information spaces (data, model, change, and history), and powerful interaction tools to support exploration and model building enable analysts to confirm the expected and guide the process of uncovering unexpected insights. 

The results of this project have significant impact in a wide range of domains that rely on extracting information from evolving digital data, including finance, medicine, and homeland security. Broader impact also includes capacity building in the form of cutting-edge software tools. These tools have been successfully applied to tackle financial risk and fraud detection problems. The resulting innovations, along with source code of the technology, are released to the public domain via the project web page (http://davis.wpi.edu/~xmdv).  Lastly, human capital building in training the future talent critical to fuel the economic prosperity of our nation is achieved by involvement of students at all levels in this project.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2016
Modified by: Elke A Rundensteiner

Images (1 of )
  • Visual display of MaVis tool capturing distinct drift abstractions of collection of 32 time series objects (prices of company stocks over time) from 2006 to 2007. Histograms show drift metrics and financial risk scores of these time series over several selected time spans.
    Image produce by MaVis tool published in Kaiyu Zhao, Matthew Ward, Elke Rundensteiner, and Huong Higgins, " MaVis: Machine Learning Aided Multi-Model Framework for Time Series Visual Analytics", Conference on Visualization and Data Analysis (VDA) 2016.
    Copyrighted

These application areas use patterns or models to differentiate behavior of varying degrees of importance or risk, both in terms of the value for a particular variable, relationships between different variables, and changes across time. This project has designed, developed, and assessed visual analytics technology to support the interactive analysis of data that focuses on creating and using complementary machine learning characterizing the data to identify instances of potentially important activities and risks in the data. This research breaks fundamentally new ground in the design of innovative exploration techniques of time-variant data sets, with a focus on visualization and interactions of competing and complementary models extracted from the data and of metrics characterizing each. Novel technology includes the integration of computational and visual methods for interactive model formation, model management and model analysis. Linked views of the different information spaces (data, model, change, and history), and powerful interaction tools to support exploration and model building enable analysts to confirm the expected and guide the process of uncovering unexpected insights. The results of this project have significant impact in a wide range of domains that rely on extracting information from evolving digital data, including finance, medicine, and homeland security. Broader impact also includes capacity building in the form of cutting-edge software tools. These tools have been successfully applied to tackle financial risk and fraud detection problems. The resulting innovations, along with source code of the technology, are released to the public domain via the project web page (http://davis.wpi.edu/~xmdv).
